49 (S) | seat_change3 = +4 | popular_vote3 = 5.343.930 | percentage3 = 13.6% | swing3 = -0.7% | title = [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]] | posttitle = New [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]] | before_election = [[Giulio Andreotti]] | before_party = Christian Democracy (Italy)|DC | after_election = [[Giuliano Amato]] | after_party = Italian Socialist Party|PSI }} The '''Italian general elections''' of 1992 were held on the 5 April 1992. The 1992 elections were the first without the traditionally second most important political force in [[Politics of Italy|Italy]], the [[Italian Communist Party]] (PCI), which had been disbanded in 1991. It was replaced by a more social-democratic oriented force, the [[Democratic Party of the Left]] (PDS), and by a minority entity formed by members who did not want to renounce the [[communism|communist]] tradition, the [[Communist Refoundation Party]] (PRC). However, put together they gained around 4% less than what the already declining PCI had obtained in the [[Italian general election, 1987|1987 Italian general election]]. The other major feature was the sudden rise of the separatist [[Lega Nord|Lombard League]], which increased its vote from c. 0.5% of the preceding elections to more than 8%, increasing from a single member both in the Chamber and the Senate to 55 and 25, respectively. The ''onda lunga'' ("long wave") of [[Bettino Craxi]]'s now [[centrism|centrist]]-oriented [[Italian Socialist Party]], which in the past elections had been forecast next to overcome PCI, seemed to stop. [[Christian Democracy (Italy)|Christian Democracy]] and the other traditional government parties (with the exception of the [[Italian Republican Party|Republican Party]]) also experienced a slight decrease in their vote. ==Results== ===Chamber of Deputies=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
